passage:
(1) The pyramids of ancient Egypt stand as some of the most remarkable architectural achievements in human history. Built primarily during the Old and Middle Kingdom periods (approximately 2700-1700 BCE), these massive stone structures served as elaborate tombs for the pharaohs who ruled Egypt. The Great Pyramid of Giza, constructed for Pharaoh Khufu, is the largest and most famous of all Egyptian pyramids, originally standing 146 meters tall with a base covering more than 13 acres.

(2) Beyond their function as royal tombs, the pyramids held profound religious significance for ancient Egyptians. They believed that the pyramid shape represented the primordial mound from which all life emerged and provided a stairway for the pharaoh's spirit to ascend to the heavens. Inside these structures, elaborate burial chambers contained not only the mummified remains of the pharaoh but also treasures, food, furniture, and other items the ruler would need in the afterlife. The precise alignment of many pyramids to celestial bodies further demonstrates their connection to Egyptian religious beliefs about the journey to the afterlife.

(3) The construction of these massive monuments required extraordinary organizational skill and engineering knowledge. Thousands of workers, contrary to popular belief that they were slaves, were actually paid laborers who worked in shifts throughout the year. They quarried enormous stone blocks, some weighing several tons, and transported them to the construction site using sledges, ropes, and water to reduce friction. With remarkable precision, workers fitted these blocks together without mortar, creating structures so well-built that they have endured for over 4,500 years despite earthquakes, weather, and even attempts at dismantling them.

(4) Pyramids also played an important economic and social role in ancient Egyptian society. Their construction provided employment for thousands of workers during the annual Nile flooding when farming was impossible. This massive public works project helped unite the population under the pharaoh's rule and demonstrated the extraordinary wealth and power of the Egyptian state. The organizational systems developed to build the pyramids likely contributed to advancements in Egyptian mathematics, astronomy, and architecture.

(5) Today, Egypt's pyramids continue to fascinate scientists, historians, and tourists alike. Modern archaeological techniques have revealed new information about how they were built and the lives of those who constructed them. While many of their treasures were looted centuries ago, the pyramids themselves remain as testament to the ingenuity and cultural beliefs of ancient Egypt. Their enduring presence has made them not only symbols of Egyptian civilization but also of human achievement, inspiring wonder across countless generations.

options.D: After the reign of Pharaoh Khufu
